title: Arithmetic progression topologies
summary: In general topology and number theory, branches of mathematics, one can define various topologies on the set Z {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} } of integers or the set Z > 0 {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} _{>0}} of positive integers by taking as a base a suitable collection of arithmetic progressions, sequences of the form { b , b + a , b + 2 a , . . . } {\displaystyle \{b,b+a,b+2a,...\}} or { . . . , b − 2 a , b − a , b , b + a , b + 2 a , . . . } . {\displaystyle \{...,b-2a,b-a,b,b+a,b+2a,...\}.} The open sets will then be unions of arithmetic progressions in the collection.  Three examples are the Furstenberg topology on Z {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} } , and the Golomb topology and the Kirch topology on Z > 0 {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} _{>0}} .
